column2:
COVID-19 negative certification required for entering the country. If you are 18 years and over, fully vaccinated and have received a booster vaccination, you can enter Aruba without needing to test. At least 7 days must have passed since your booster vaccination and the vaccine must be approved.
If you’re not fully vaccinated, you’ll need to show proof of a negative antigen test (taken no more than 24 hours before departure) or PCR test (taken no more than 3 days before departure.
column3: Self-isolation at own accommodation- subject to PCR. A health screening and temperature check will be carried out on arrival. Further information on testing and screening is available on the website of the Government of Aruba.
column4: If you are 18 years and over, fully vaccinated and have received a booster vaccination, you can enter Aruba without needing to test. At least 7 days must have passed since your booster vaccination and the vaccine must be approved by the European Medicine Agency or the Food and Drug Administration.Find out if you qualify as fully vaccinated in Aruba on the website of the Government of Aruba .
column5:
Latest News: Authorities lift all COVID-19-related entry requirements for all international travelers from 19 March (Travel Agent Central, 18.03.2022)

International Restrictions:
*All travellers: You must get approval to travel to Aruba through the embarkation / disembarkation card online before departure. This includes taking out mandatory insurance. Visit the website of the Government of Aruba for the latest information.
If you’re fully vaccinated: If you are 18 years and over, fully vaccinated and have received a booster vaccination, you can enter Aruba without needing to test. At least 7 days must have passed since your booster vaccination and the vaccine must be approved by the European Medicine Agency or the Food and Drug Administration.Find out if you qualify as fully vaccinated in Aruba on the website of the Government of Aruba . Proof of vaccination status: You must present proof that you have been fully vaccinated to enter Aruba. The proof of the booster needs to be uploaded as part of the embarkation / disembarkation card process. Information on proof of vaccination status can be found on the Aruba website. Residents of Aruba: The rules apply to vaccinated residents but residents do not need to take out mandatory insurance as part of the embarkation / disembarkation process.
If you’re not fully vaccinated: If you’re not fully vaccinated, you’ll need to show proof of a negative antigen test (taken no more than 24 hours before departure) or PCR test (taken no more than 3 days before departure.
More information is available on the website of the government of Aruba. If you’ve had COVID-19 in the past year: If you’re not fully vaccinated but have tested positive for COVID-19 recently you can enter Aruba. You’ll need to show evidence of a positive PCR test, taken between at least 10 days and not more than 12 weeks ago. You do not need to take an additional COVID-19 test.
Residents of Aruba: The rules apply to unvaccinated residents, however residents have the option of taking a pre-departure test to take a test upon arrival at their own expense, instead.
Children and young people: Children aged between 12 and 17 can enter Aruba with a COVID-19 vaccination certificate showing that they were fully vaccinated with the primary series (fully vaccinated without a booster) at least 14 days before arrival in Aruba.
Children aged 11 and under do not need to show proof of a negative COVID-19 test or proof of vaccination to enter Aruba. If you’re transiting through Aruba: Travellers who are transiting without entering Aruba don’t need a negative test. You will need to complete the embarkation / disembarkation process .

Internal Restrictions:
*Travel in Aruba: The Government of Aruba has put measures in place in response to the coronavirus pandemic. such as the mandatory wearing of face masks in all public indoor spaces. All measures and updates can be found on thewebsite of the government of Aruba .
